text: Efficient fabrication of ordered mesoporous carbon derived from lignin via deep eutectic solvent pretreatment for supercapacitors
Guobao Sima , Linhuo Gan \*, Longjun Chang , Ying Cui , Ranjith Kumar Kankala
College of Chemical Engineering, Huaqiao University, Xiamen, 361021, PR China
Keywords: Alkali lignin Porous carbon Green technology Phenolic resin Supercapacitor
A B S T R A C T

Lignin can be used as a green and sustainable substitute for phenol in the preparation of ordered mesoporous carbon using phenol resin prepolymer as precursor owing to the availability of aromatic ortho-positions in the lignin structure. To further improve the reactivity towards formaldehyde and increase the substitution degree of phenol, masson pine alkali lignin (MAL) was pretreated by an acidic deep eutectic solvent (DES). It was found that adding an appropriate amount of water to DES showed beneficial attributions to the reduction in pre­ treatment time and the upsurge in the phenolic hydroxyl content of regenerated lignin (DAL). The content of $\beta$ -O4 ether bond in MAL was almost cleaved. More importantly, the contents of syringyl and guaiacyl units were decreased. In contrast, the content of $p$ -hydroxyphenyl (H) units was increased obviously, thereby facilitating lignin to react with formaldehyde. Results showed that the optimized DAL with higher content of H units was an appropriate candidate for substituting $1 0 0 \%$ of phenol in the preparation of highly-ordered lignin-derived mesoporous carbon (LDMC). Finally, the optimized LDMC exhibited high specific capacitance of $1 9 7 . 3 2 \mathrm { F } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ at current density of $0 . 2 \mathrm { ~ A ~ g ^ { - 1 } }$ , high capacitance retention of $8 4 \%$ at current density of $2 0 \textrm { A g } ^ { - 1 }$ , superior cyclic stability with capacitance retention rate of $9 9 . 0 9 \%$ after 10000 cycles and high energy density of $6 . 8 5 \mathrm { W h } { \cdot } \mathrm { k g } ^ { - 1 }$ at power density of $1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { W ~ k g ^ { - 1 } }$ .
1. Introduction

Ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC) has gained enormous attention from researchers owing to its various advantages such as high specific surface area, ordered mesostructure, adjustable pore diameter, low cost, good electronic conductivity, excellent chemical and thermal stability [1,2]. OMC is considered as an ideal electrode material for high per­ formance energy storage devices, especially supercapacitors [3,4]. Generally, OMC contains multi-scale pores (micropore $\cdot { < } 2 \ \mathrm { n m } \rangle$ , meso­ pore $\left( 2 { - } 5 0 \ \mathrm { n m } \right)$ and macropore $\mathrm { ( > 5 0 ~ n m ) }$ ), which provides sufficient space for the mass transfer of ions and maximizes the specific capaci­ tance of supercapacitor [5]. It was reported that micropores provided active sites for storing energy in the adsorption-desorption process of electrolyte ions, but most micropores could not contact electrolyte so­ lution directly due to their closed-pores and narrow bottle-necks [6]. Fortunately, uniform and interpenetrating mesoporous channels could not only promote surface access, but also help electrolyte ions reach micropores by providing a wider transport path [7]. Besides, macro­ pores could be used as ion buffer reservoirs [8]. Therefore, multi-layer interconnected ordered porous carbon with macropores, mesopores and micropores (such as OMC) employed as electrode material is one of the effective ways to prepare supercapacitors with excellent electro­ chemical properties.

In general, petroleum-based phenols such as phenol, resorcinol, and phloroglucinol are used as carbon resources in the synthesis of OMC [9]. However, due to the depletion of oil resources, it is imperative to find renewable alternatives. Lignin, the second most abundant natural biopolymer after cellulose [10], offers enormous beneficial character­ istics, such as aromatic structure similar to phenol, wide sources, low cost and renewability, making it a high-quality carbon source for the sustainable synthesis of OMC [11]. Furthermore, it is evident that the availability of aromatic ortho-positions (C-3 and C-5) in lignin structure plays a vital role in making lignin a green and sustainable substitute for phenol in the preparation of phenolic resin-based functional materials. However, many of the ortho-positions of phenol hydroxyl (ArOH) groups are occupied by methoxyl groups, which may limit the substitution degree of phenol while fabricating the ordered lignin-derived meso­ porous carbon (LDMC) [12]. Several efforts had been dedicated to facilitating lignin valorization in the synthesis of LDMC. Methanol-soluble fraction of hardwood alkali lignin was used to react with formaldehyde for preparing LDMC with specific surface area and mesopore volume of $4 1 \bar { 8 } \ \mathrm { { m } ^ { 2 } \mathrm { { g } ^ { - 1 } } }$ and $0 . 3 4 ~ \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 } \ : \bar { \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 } }$ [9], but leading to an under-utilization of alkali lignin. Softwood lignin containing a higher content of guaiacyl (G) unit than that of syringyl (S) unit was employed to synthesize LDMC with specific surface area and pore volume of $4 6 6 ~ \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } ~ \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ and $0 . 6 2 \ \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 } \ \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ , reflecting that lignin with low molecular weight and high ArOH content was conducive to the formation of OMC [13]. Using phenolization method, the molecular weight of masson pine alkali lignin (MAL) was decreased and its $\mathrm { \bf A r O H }$ content was increased simultaneously [14], thereby improving its reactivity towards formal­ dehyde and obtaining a highly-ordered LDMC with specific surface area and mesopore volume of $\bar { 2 6 2 } \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ and $0 . 0 6 7 ~ \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 } \bar { \mathrm { \Phi g } } ^ { - 1 }$ [15]. However, the substitution degree of phenol was only $2 5 \ \mathrm { w t \% }$ . To facilitate the utilization of lignin as a high-quality supplier of aromatic compounds and reduce the dependence on oil, it is promising and urgent to modify the structure of industrial lignin via green technology.

In recent years, deep eutectic solvent (DES), a kind of green solvent, has been widely used in the fractionation of lignocellulose or lignin extraction owing to various advantages [16–19]. Due to the mild acid-base catalysis mechanism provided from DES, unstable ether bonds and some C–C bonds between phenylpropane units in lignin structure could be broken [20], thus resulting in the depolymerization of lignin macromolecule and the regeneration of lignin fractions with higher ArOH content, lower molecular weight and nano size [21]. Moreover, it was found that the addition of a third component (such as alcohols [22], lewis acids [23], water (W) [24], etc.) to binary DES could modulate the physicochemical properties of DES to a certain extent and enhance its pretreatment effectiveness upon lignocellulose. Among them, water has low viscosity, low cost, wide sources, and it is one of the few natural substances that can act as a hydrogen bond donor or a hydrogen bond acceptor [25–27]. Therefore, the addition of a certain amount of water as a third component could decrease the viscosity of DES dramatically, thus stimulating the mass transfer and adjusting the interactions among DES components, and leading to an improvement of pretreatment effi­ ciency of DES on lignocellulose [26,28].

Inspired by these aspects, herein, we intend to demonstrate the modification of MAL by the pretreatment with acidic DES synthesized from formic acid (F) and choline chloride (ChCl) with or without water. Further, the effects of main factors on the DES pretreatment efficiency were explored, respectively. The influence of W addition on the viscosity and hydrogen bonding interaction of DES was investigated to better understand the role of W in the DES pretreatment process of MAL. Moreover, the structures of MAL and regenerated lignin (DAL) were characterized systematically. Finally, the optimized DAL with more reactive sites towards formaldehyde was employed to prepare highlyordered LDMC by replacing $1 0 0 \%$ of phenol and utilize it as electrode material of supercapacitor.
2. Experimental
2.1. Materials

MAL was purchased from Nanping Paper-making Co., Ltd. (Nanping, China). Moreover, the contents of MAL components $( 8 0 . 9 4 \mathrm { w t \% }$ of lignin and $1 8 . 5 7 ~ \mathrm { w t \% }$ of hemicellulose) were determined according to the method described in the literature [29]. Choline chloride $( \geq 9 8 \% )$ and 1, 4-dioxane (HPLC, $\geq 9 9 . 5 \%$ ) were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Pluronic F127 was supplied by Sigma Chemical Reagents Ltd. 1,2,4-trimethylbenzene was purchased from Shanghai Macleans Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Phenol, formaldehyde $3 7 \%$ aqueous solution), formic acid $( \geq 8 8 \% )$ ), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, ${ > } 9 6 \%$ ), potassium hydroxide (KOH, ${ > } 9 9 . 5 \% )$ , ethanol $( > 9 9 . 7 \% )$ , and concentrated hydrochloric acid (HCl, $3 7 \%$ ) were purchased from Xilong Science Co., Ltd. (Guangzhou, China).
2.2. DES synthesis, MAL pretreatment and lignin recovery

Initially, ChCl was dried at $8 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 6 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ and cooled to room tem­ perature in a desiccator. ChCl and F were mixed in the sealed glass bottles at different molar ratios (1:1–4), and placed in a water bath with magnetic stirring at $7 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ until obtaining clear and transparent liquids. The as-prepared binary DESs were stored in a desiccator prior to use. Then, adding a certain amount of deionized water into the mixture of ChCl and F (molar ratio of 1:2) and being stirred to prepare uniform ternary DESs with different mass ratio of W to ChCl and F (1:8, 1:6, 1:4, 1:2 and 1:1). Finally, the corresponding DES was named DES-W-x/y, where $x / y$ represented the mass ratio of W to ChCl and F.

MAL was mixed with binary DES (DES-W-0/1) at a mass ratio of 1:20 in a sealed glass bottle and stirred magnetically in an oil bath at different temperature (90, 105, 120, 135 and $1 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ in a given period of time (1, 2, 3, 4.5, 6, and $7 . 5 ~ \mathrm { h } \dot { } .$ . After pretreatment, 9-fold volume of aqueous ethanol $( 9 0 \% )$ was added and stirred vigorously for $^ \textrm { \scriptsize 1 h }$ . Then, the resultant precipitated lignin was washed several times with aqueous ethanol until the filtrate was neutralized, and the regenerated lignin was freeze-dried.

Simultaneously, the pretreatment process of MAL using ternary DES (DES-W-x/y $( x { \neq } 0 )$ ) was performed similarly to that using binary DES (DES-W-0/1). The regenerated lignin obtained after the pretreatment of ternary DES was labeled as DAL-W-x/y.
2.3. LDMC preparation

The synthesis process of LDMC is shown in Figure S1. Initially, $2 . 0 \ : \mathrm { g }$ of MAL/the optimized DAL, $4 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of aqueous ethanol $( 5 0 \% )$ and $_ { 0 . 1 \ g }$ of NaOH were mixed in a sealed pressure glass bottle, and the mixture was continuously stirred until lignin was dissolved completely. Then, $3 . 4 5 ~ \mathrm { \ m L }$ of formaldehyde solution was added to the mixture and refluxed at $7 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 1 2 \mathrm { h } }$ to synthesize phenolic resin derived from MAL (named as MALPF) or DAL (named as DALPF).

Next, $3 . 4 8 ~ \mathrm { g }$ of F127, $2 . 1 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ of 1,2,4-trimethyl benzene, $1 . 6 5 \mathrm { m L }$ of concentrated HCl and $7 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of ethanol were added into a stoppered Erlenmeyer flask, which was placed in a water bath at $4 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ with magnetic stirring to form a clear solution. Then, MALPF or DALPF was added into the solution dropwise, and the pH value of mixed solution was adjusted to 1 using $2 ~ \mathrm { m o l ~ L } ^ { - 1 }$ HCl with vigorous stirring at room temperature for $^ { 4 \mathrm { h } }$ . The above solution was decanted into a Petri dish and volatilized at room temperature for $2 4 \mathrm { h }$ to form a transparent film. Then, the thermal polymerization was conducted further in an oven at $1 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $2 4 \mathrm { h }$ . And the carbonization process was carried out according to our previous experimental procedures [1]. Finally, the LDMCs pre­ pared from MAL or the optimized DAL (named as LDMC-MAL or LDMC-DAL) were obtained after being cooled to room temperature in the atmosphere of nitrogen.
2.4. Characterizations
2.4.1. Lignin characterizations

ArOH content of lignin was measured using an ultraviolet–visible (UV–Vis) spectrophotometer (UV-8000, China) according to the method described in the literature [30]. Firstly, $0 . 2 \mathrm { m o l } \mathrm { L } ^ { - 1 }$ NaOH solution was prepared and labeled as solvent A, and $1 0 ~ \mathrm { m g }$ of lignin sample was dissolved in $1 0 \mathrm { m L }$ of 1,4-dioxane/A mixture $( 1 / 1 , \mathbf { v } / \mathbf { v } )$ . Secondly, $2 \mathrm { m L }$ of the above lignin solution was filtered by whatman Grade 1 filter paper and diluted with $2 5 \mathrm { m L }$ of phosphate buffer solution at $\mathtt { p H } 6$ and solvent A, respectively. Thirdly, the absorbance values of lignin solutions in the wavelength range of $2 0 0 { - } 4 5 0 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ were recorded on a UV–Vis spectro­ photometer using lignin solution at $\mathtt { p H } 6$ as a reference. Finally, the total ArOH content of lignin was calculated using the following equation (1):

$$
\mathrm { T o t a l ~ A r O H ~ ( m m o l \cdot g - 1 ) } = ( 0 . 2 5 0 \times \Delta \alpha 3 0 0 ) + ( 0 . 1 0 7 \times \Delta 3 6 0 )
$$
where $\varDelta \alpha _ { 3 0 0 }$ and $\varDelta \alpha _ { 3 6 0 }$ are the absorbance values at the wavelength of ${ 3 0 0 } \mathrm { n m }$ and $3 6 0 ~ \mathrm { { n m } }$ , respectively.

The particle size of MAL was measured by a laser particle size analyzer (LS 1332, USA), while the particle size of DAL was measured using dynamic light scattering (DLS), and data were collected at $3 2 3 . 1 5 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ on a zeta potential analyzer (NanoBrook Omni, Brookhaven Instruments, USA).

Before GPC analysis, to increase the solubility of lignin in tetrahy­ drofuran (THF), lignin samples were acetylated according to our pre­ vious work [14]. $2 0 ~ \mathrm { m g }$ of acetylated lignin was dissolved in $1 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of THF, and the mixture was filtered with a $0 . 2 2 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ filter membrane to remove insoluble particles. Then, GPC analyzer (Water GPC 1515， USA) with an Agilent Plogel $5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ MIXED-C column was employed at a THF flow rate of $1 \ \mathrm { m L / m i n }$ .

2D-HSQC NMR spectrum was detected using a Bruker AVANCE III 500MHZ NMR instrument (Switzerland). $8 0 ~ \mathrm { m g }$ of lignin sample was dissolved in $0 . 6 { \mathrm { ~ m L } }$ of deuterated dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO $. d _ { 6 }$ ) at $2 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } .$ . $^ 1 \mathrm { H }$ and $^ { 1 3 } \mathrm { C }$ dimensions have spectral widths of $0 { \mathrm { - } } 1 2 { \mathrm { ~ p p m } }$ and $0 { - } 1 6 0 \ \mathrm { p p m }$ , respectively. The number of sampling points in the $^ 1 \mathrm { H }$ dimension is around 1024 with relaxation time of $1 . 0 ~ s$ and accumula­ tion of 32 times, and the number of sampling points in the $^ { 1 3 } \mathrm { C }$ dimension is around 256.

The thermal stability of lignin sample was performed on a ther­ mogravimetric analyzer (Shimadzu DTG-60H, Japan). Approximately $5 \mathrm { m g }$ of lignin sample was heated from room temperature to $7 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ at a heating rate of $1 0 \ { ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C / m i n } }$ under the condition of nitrogen purge.
The surface morphology of lignin sample was observed using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) (Hitachi S-4800, Japan).
2.4.2. DES characterizations

The viscosity of DES was determined using a viscometer fitted with a thermostated jacket (Brookfield DV-E, USA). $^ 1 \mathrm { H }$ NMR spectra of the binary DES and the ternary DES were obtained using DMSO‑ $. d _ { 6 }$ as an external reference.
2.4.3. LDMC characterizations
Transmission electron microscope (TEM) image of LDMC sample was recorded on a $2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { k V }$ field emission transmission electron microscope (FEI Tecnai G2 F20, USA).

Small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) patterns were recorded using a X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Smart Lab, Japan) under the conditions of $4 0 \mathrm { k V }$ and $4 0 ~ \mathrm { { m A } }$ with CuKα radiation and a 2θ range of $0 . 6 ^ { \circ } - 5 ^ { \circ }$ .

The textural properties of LDMC in terms of porosity and specific surface area were demonstrated in nitrogen adsorption-desorption iso­ therms obtained using a gas adsorption analyzer at $- 1 9 6 \ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ (Micro­ meritics 3 Flex, USA). Brunauer-Emmett-teller (BET) model was used to calculate the specific surface area of LDMC, and its average pore diameter was calculated by nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) model, the mesoporous pore volume and diameter of LDMC were calculated using Barrette-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method.
2.4.4. Electrochemical measurements

A definite volume of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) was dropped into the mixture of LDMC, acetylene black and poly (vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) at a mass ratio of 8:1:1, and then fully stirring them to form a uniform slurry that is evenly applied to the surface of nickel foam. Then, the electrode material was dried for $^ { 1 2 \mathrm { h } }$ under the vacuum condition of $1 2 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } .$ . The mass loading of LDMC used for the preparation of electrode was about $8 { \cdot } 9 ~ \mathrm { m g ~ c m } ^ { - 2 }$ . In the electrolyte solution of $6 ~ \mathrm { m o l } ~ \mathrm { L } ^ { - 1 }$ KOH, the measurements of cyclic voltammetry (CV), galvanostatic chargedischarge (GCD) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were conducted on a electrochemical workstation (CHI660E, China) with a two-electrode configuration. Specific capacitance $( \mathsf { C } _ { \mathsf { s } } , \mathsf { \Pi } _ { \mathsf { F } } \mathsf { \Pi } _ { \mathsf { g } } ^ { - 1 } )$ , energy density (E, ${ \mathbf { { w h } } } { \cdot } { \mathbf { k g } } ^ { - 1 } .$ ) and power density (P, W $\mathbf { k g } ^ { - 1 }$ ) were calculated according to the following equations (2)–(4), respectively.
where i (A), Δt (s), ΔV (V) and $m \left( { \mathfrak { g } } \right)$ are discharging current, discharging time, potential interval, and the mass of a single electrode material, respectively.
3. Results and discussion
3.1. Optimization of DES pretreatment of MAL

Previous reports indicated that DES could promote the controlled cleavage of unstable ether bonds between phenylpropane units or the selective deconstruction of some C–C bonds, thereby reducing the mo­ lecular weight of lignin and increasing the ArOH content in lignin structure [18,20]. To demonstrate these aspects, the pretreatment pro­ cess with a binary DES synthesized by ChCl and F was performed. And the effects of the molar ratio of $\mathrm { C h C l }$ to F, pretreatment temperature and time on the particle size and ArOH content of regenerated lignin were investigated, and the result is shown in Fig. 1.

As depicted in Fig. 1a, the ArOH content of regenerated lignin is initially increased and then decreased at $1 2 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $6 \mathrm { h }$ with the decrease in the molar ratio of ChCl to F. Meanwhile, the particle size of DAL is first reduced and then increased with the decrease in the molar ratio of ChCl to F. Notably, the maximum ArOH content $( 2 . 9 9 \mathrm { \ m m o l g ^ { - 1 } } )$ and the minimum particle size $( 2 4 9 \mathrm { n m } )$ ) of DAL are obtained at molar ratio of ChCl to F of 1:2. Seen from Fig. 1b, it is observed that under the con­ ditions of molar ratio of ChCl to F of 1:2 and ${ 1 2 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } } _ { : }$ the ArOH content of DAL is slowly increased initially and then slightly reduced with pro­ longing pretreatment time, and the maximum ArOH content of DAL is obtained at $^ { 6 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ . Contrarily, the effect of pretreatment time on the par­ ticle size of DAL is not apparent. As shown in Fig. 1c, the maximum ArOH content and the minimum particle size of DAL are obtained at $1 2 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ . Conclusively, after binary DES (ChCl-F) pretreatment without water, the ArOH content and particle size of regenerated lignin are of $2 . 9 9 \ \mathrm { m m o l g ^ { - 1 } }$ (increased by $7 3 . 8 \%$ compared to the ArOH content of MAL $( 1 . 7 2 ~ \mathrm { m m o l g } ^ { - 1 } )$ ) and $2 4 9 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ under the optimized conditions of molar ratio of ChCl to F of 1:2, pretreatment time and temperature of 6 h and ${ 1 2 0 } ^ { \circ } \mathsf { C } ,$ , respectively.

In general, the addition of a third component may influence and substantially regulate the physicochemical properties of DES, thereby tuning its pretreatment effectiveness on lignin [26]. In this work, to develop a “hybrid green” system [31], water is selected as the third component to synthesis a ternary DES composed of ChCl, F and W at a fixed molar ratio of ChCl to F of 1:2. During the pretreatment process of the ternary DES, the effects of mass ratio of W to ChCl and F, pretreat­ ment time and temperature on the particle size and ArOH content of DAL were investigated, and the result is shown in Fig. 2.

It is observed from Fig. 2a that under the conditions of $^ { 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ and $1 2 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } ,$ the mass ratio of W to ChCl and F exerts a significant effect on the particle size and ArOH content of DAL. With an increase in W con­ tent, both particle size and ArOH content of DAL show mixed trends of an initial upsurge and then a slightly reduction. Notably, the maximum values of $3 . 3 6 \mathrm { m m o l g } ^ { - 1 }$ and $4 0 0 \ \mathrm { n m }$ are obtained at mass ratio of W to ChCl and F of 1:4. As depicted in Fig. 2b, under the conditions of mass ratio of W to ChCl and $\boldsymbol { \mathrm { ~ F ~ } }$ of 1:4 and ${ 1 2 0 \ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } } ,$ particle size and ArOH content of DAL are initially increased and then decreased with pro­ longing pretreatment time. It should be noted that the pretreatment time needed to reach the maximum ArOH content is only $^ { 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ . According to Fig. 2c, with prolonging pretreatment temperature, the ArOH content of DAL is first increased and then decreased slightly. Contrarily, the par­ ticle size of DAL is reduced and then increased under the conditions of mass ratio of W to ChCl and F of 1:4 and pretreatment time of $^ { 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ . Accordingly, after the pretreatment of ternary DES (DES-W-x/y), the ArOH content and particle size of DAL (DAL-W-1/4) are up to $3 . 3 6 ~ \mathrm { m m o l g ^ { - 1 } }$ (increased by $9 5 . 3 \%$ compared to the ArOH content of MAL) and $4 0 0 \mathrm { n m }$ under the optimized conditions of molar ratio of ChCl to F of 1:2, mass ratio of W to ChCl and F of 1:4, pretreatment time and temperature of $^ { 2 \mathrm { h } }$ and $1 2 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ , respectively.

img_caption: Fig. 1. Effects of (a) molar ratio of ChCl to F, (b) pretreatment time and (c) pretreatment temperature on the particle size and ArOH content of regenerated lignin.
Fig. 2. Effects of (a) mass ratio of W to ChCl and F, (b) pretreatment time and (c) pretreatment temperature on the particle size and ArOH content of regener­ ated lignin.

text: Based on the comprehensive comparisons of the optimized condi­ tions and pretreatment efficiency between binary DES and ternary DES for MAL, it is found that adding a certain amount of water to binary DES can shorten the optimal pretreatment time significantly (decreasing from $^ { 6 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ to $2 ~ \mathrm { h } \dot { } .$ ). Although the particle size of DAL is increased from $2 4 9 \ \mathrm { n m }$ to $4 0 0 \ \mathrm { n m }$ , its ArOH content is increased obviously from $2 . 9 9 \ \mathrm { m m o l g } ^ { - 1 }$ to $3 . 3 6 \ \mathrm { m m o l g } ^ { - 1 }$ , providing more reactive functional groups and active sites for the further high-value utilization of lignin.

To better understand the potential contribution of water to the lignin pretreatment using ternary DES, the effect of mass ratio of W to ChCl and F on the viscosity and hydrogen bonds of DES was investigated, respectively. Notably, viscosity, one of the essential physical properties of a liquid, plays a crucial role in electrical conductivity and mass transfer, affecting its suitability in specific applications [26,28]. As depicted in Figure S2a, the viscosity of DES is decreased rapidly at room temperature with increasing the amount of water added until it is close to the viscosity of water $\mathbf { \langle 0 . 8 9 m P a \cdot s \rangle }$ . In general, most DESs have large ion sizes, tiny void volumes, numerous hydrogen bonds and other in­ teractions such as electrostatic forces or van der Waals interactions among the components of DES, resulting in a high viscosity of DES [32]. It should be noted that, in the case of adding a small amount of deionized water with low density and viscosity, the hydrogen bonds between the components of binary DES are weakened, and the viscosity of DES is decreased until it reaches the viscosity of water. As depicted in the $^ 1 \mathrm { H }$ NMR spectra of DESs (DES-W–x/y) (Figure S2b), the chemical shifts of protons of ChCl and F move to the low frequency (high energy field) due to the weakening of their intramolecular hydrogen bonds and the for­ mation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds between ChCl and F. Notably, compared to binary DES without water (DES-W-0/1), according to the appearance of new chemical shift of hydrogen protons between 4 ppm and 7 ppm shown in Figure S2b, it is observed that the addition of water can destroy the hydrogen bonds between ChCl and F gradually, resulting in the formation of new hydrogen bonds between ChCl and W. With an increase in the amount of water added, the new chemical shift of hydrogen protons moves to the low frequency. Moreover, it approaches the chemical shift of hydrogen protons of pure water, indicating that the supramolecular structure of DES originated from the intermolecular hydrogen bond network may be destructed intensively with adding an excessive amount of water. Therefore, the ternary DES (DES-W-1/4) formed by adding an appropriate amount of water (mass ratio of W to ChCl and F of 1:4) can not only maintain its supramolecular structure to a certain extent, but also reduce its viscosity significantly, thereby enhancing its pretreatment efficiency upon MAL [28].

img_caption: Fig. 3. 2D-HSQC NMR spectra of MAL and DAL-W-1/4. (A, A′) $\beta$ -aryl-ether (β-O-4); (B) Resin alcohol substructure $( { \mathfrak { \beta } } \mathfrak { - } \beta ) ;$ (C) phenyl coumarin substructure (β-5); (F) P-hydroxycinnamyl alcohol end group; (P-CA) $p$ -coumaric acid; (FA) ferulic acid; (H) P-hydroxyphenyl unit; (HK) Hibbert’s ketone; (G) Guaiacyl unit; (S) Syringyl unit; (S′) Oxidized syringyl unit with a carbonyl group at $\mathbf { C } _ { \alpha }$ .

text: 3.2. Structural characterizations of MAL and DAL

2D-HSQC NMR is an effective tool to characterize the structure of lignin macromolecule. As shown in Fig. 3, the 2D-HSQC NMR spectra of lignin can be divided into two main regions of the side-chain region $( \delta _ { \mathsf { C } } /$ $\delta _ { \mathrm { H } } ~ 5 0 { - } 9 0 / 2 . 5 { - } 6 . 0 )$ and the aromatic region $( \delta _ { \mathrm { C } } / \delta _ { \mathrm { H } } ~ 1 0 0 - 1 6 0 / 6 . 0 - 8 . 0 )$ [33–36]. The signals appeared in the side-chain region of 2D-HSQC NMR spectra have provided crucial information about the linkages be­ tween different units in the lignin fractions, such as $\beta$ -O-4, $_ { \beta - 5 }$ and $_ { \beta - \beta }$ [35]. Moreover, the signals occurring in the aromatic region have pre­ sented other significant information about three structural units of syringyl, guaiacyl and $p$ -hydroxyphenyl (H) regarding lignin structure.

The primary peak assignments are listed in Table S1, according to the literature [35,37]. Furthermore, the relative contents of structural mo­ tifs in MAL and the optimized regenerated lignin (DAL-W-1/4) were calculated using a semi-quantitative method based on the 2D-HSQC NMR spectra (Fig. 3). Compared to MAL, the relative content of $\beta$ -O-4 linkage in DAL-W-1/4 is reduced by $8 4 . 5 5 \%$ . Simultaneously, the cor­ responding signal originated from Hibbert’s ketone is detected in DAL-W-1/4, highlighting the cleavage of $\beta { - } O { - } 4$ linkage [35]. These experimental results indicate that an increase in the ArOH content of lignin can be ascribed to the breakage of $\beta$ -O-4 bonds.

Interestingly, it is observed from Fig. 3 that the relative content of $\beta$ -O-4 connected to S units (A(S)) drops from $3 1 . 1 4 \%$ to $2 . 2 1 \%$ , while the relative content of $\beta$ -O-4 linked to G or H units (A (G/H)) only decreases from $5 . 6 3 \%$ to $3 . 4 7 \%$ . The former has a much higher degree of cleavage than the latter, demonstrating an easier dissociation of $\beta$ -O-4 bond in A (S), which is in agreement with the conclusion drawn by Shen and colleagues [16,36]. Except for the fracture of $\beta$ -O-4 ether bond, the disappearance of $\mathbf { C } _ { \boldsymbol { \gamma } }$ signal in DAL-W-1/4 reflects that C–C bond $( { \beta } \mathrm { - } { \beta } )$ can also be cleaved. In the aromatic region of 2D-HSQC NMR spectra, aro­ matic rings can be ascribed to lignin structural units (S, G, and H) and

-hydroxycinnamates (P-CA and FA). The intensity of signal attributed to H units in the structure of DAL-W-1/4 is enhanced significantly. Be­ sides, the signals originated from P-CA and FA are disappeared. It is also observed that the relative contents of S and G units in DAL-W-1/4 are decreased from $5 4 . 7 9 \%$ to $1 5 . 0 7 \% - 3 9 . 0 6 \%$ and $1 0 . 9 7 \%$ , respectively, while the relative content of H units is increased from $3 0 . 1 4 \%$ to $4 9 . 9 7 \%$ (listed in Fig. 3). These experimental results show that the depolymer­ ization of MAL is more likely to occur on S units during the pretreatment process of DES-W-1/4. Moreover, the increase in the ArOH content of lignin is mainly due to the increase in the relative content of H units. According to the literature [38], the ability of lignin to substitute phenol in the preparation of phenolic resin was closely related to the number of active sites for the reaction with formaldehyde. More G and H units could provide more ortho-positions (C-3 and C-5) as active sites (as shown in Figure S3). Fortunately, DAL-W-1/4 with many active sites mentioned above via DES-W-1/4 pretreatment is very suitable for the preparation of phenolic resin-based functional materials, such as OMC prepared from phenolic resin as carbon precursor using soft-template method.

The morphologies of MAL and DAL-W-1/4 are presented in Fig. 4a and b. After DES pretreatment, the particle size of lignin is decreased dramatically from $1 5 8 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (Figure S4) to $4 4 \mathrm { n m }$ (Fig. 4b). Because DALW-1/4 contains a number of hydrophilic groups such as ArOH groups, the resultant hydrodynamic diameter (particle size) determined using DLS will be larger than the particle size obtained by SEM. Thus, the particle size of DAL-W-1/4 ( ${ \sim } 4 0 0 \mathrm { n m } ,$ measured by DLS (Fig. 2) is much larger than those obtained by SEM observations [39,40]. Furthermore, it is observed from Fig. 4c that the molecular weight distribution of lignin after DES pretreatment becomes narrower. Moreover, the molecular weight and polydispersity index of DAL-W-1/4 are much lower than those of MAL, thus confirming an occurrence of the depolymerization of lignin macromolecules.

img_caption: Fig. 4. SEM images of (a) MAL and (b) DAL-W-1/4 with a particle size distribution, (c) GPC curves of MAL and DAL-W-1/4 and (d) TGA curves of MAL and DAL-W1/4.

text: In addition, through comparing the TGA curves of MAL and DAL-W1/4 (Fig. 4d), it is found that two lignin samples show a similar thermal decomposition process. The first stage of weight loss (before $1 6 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ is related to the evaporation of water and small organic compounds including ArOH groups. Thus, compared to MAL, a more significant weight loss of DAL-W-1/4 is probably due to an increase in the ArOH content of the former [21,41]. Most $\beta { - } O { - } 4$ ether linkages in the lignin structure will be decomposed within the temperature range of $2 0 0 { - } 4 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ [42,43]. Furthermore, it is observed from Fig. 4d that the temperature corresponding to the maximum decomposition rate $\mathrm { ( T _ { m a x } ) }$ of MAL $( \sim 2 7 6 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ is higher than that of DAL-W-1/4 $( \sim 2 5 6 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ , which may be due to the much higher molecular weight and relative content of $\beta$ -O-4 ether linkage of the former $( 7 0 3 3 \ g \ m o l ^ { - 1 }$ and $3 6 . 7 7 \% )$ than those of the latter $( 2 9 8 0 \ g \ m o l ^ { - 1 }$ and $5 . 6 8 \%$ ). Compared to MAL, the ther­ mostability of DAL-W-1/4 obtained after DES-W-1/4 pretreatment is improved to a certain extent in the experimental temperature range.
3.3. Evaluation of DES pretreatment effectiveness

In this study, to evaluate the effectiveness of aqueous DES pretreat­ ment upon lignin, MAL and DAL-W-1/4 were employed to replace $1 0 0 \%$ of phenol in the synthesis of LDMCs using soft-template method, respectively. It can be observed in Fig. 5a that the mesostructure of LDMC-MAL is unordered, but the orderliness of LDMC-DAL is obvious (Fig. 5b). In fact, within the cross-linking between MALPF and F127 under acidic condition, it is observed that a phenomenon of precipita­ tion occurs in the mixture solution. Interesting, there is not a similar phenomenon during the cross-linking between DALPF and F127 under the same condition, but forming a clear solution (Figure S5). These experimental results confirm a high pretreatment effectiveness on the improvement of lignin reactivity towards formaldehyde. Therefore, the LDMC prepared from DAL-W-1/4 at a substitution degree of phenol of $1 0 0 \%$ has a highly ordered mesostructure with a regularly arranged fringe crystal structure (Fig. 5b). In addition, the SAXS pattern of LDMC

DAL (Fig. 5c) shows that there are two peaks around $2 \theta = 1 . 0 ^ { \circ }$ and $2 \theta = 1 . 4 ^ { \circ }$ , which are attributed to (100) and (110) of 2D P6mm hexag­ onal crystal structure [1,13], further verifying the existence of ordered mesostructure in LDMC-DAL mentioned above. Nevertheless, two typical peaks can be observed in the Raman spectra of LDMCs (Fig. 5d). Among them, G peak at $1 5 9 0 \mathrm { c m } ^ { - 1 }$ is ascribed to the stretching vibration of $ { s p } ^ { 2 }$ carbon pair in the ring and chain, referring to a graphite structure; D peak at $1 3 4 0 ~ \mathrm { c m } ^ { - 1 }$ is assigned to the disorder and defect degree of carbon material. Indeed, $\mathrm { I _ { D } / I _ { G } }$ value is usually used to evaluate the graphitization degree and orderliness of carbon materials [44,45]. As shown in Table 1, the $\mathrm { I _ { D } / I _ { G } }$ value of LDMC-DAL is slightly lower than that of LDMC-MAL, indicating a higher graphitization degree of the former.

According to the IUPAC classification, the ${ \bf N } _ { 2 }$ adsorption-desorption isotherms of LDMCs (Fig. 5e) have shown a typical type-IV curve with a clear H4 hysteresis loop, highlighting the mesoporous characteristics [13,46–48]. Moreover, seen from Fig. 5f, it is observed that LDMC is a kind of hierarchical porous carbons that possess multi-modal pore size distribution of micropore, mesopore and macropore. The data of the textural properties of two LDMCs are listed in Table 1. Result shows that the specific surface area and total pore volume of LDMC-DAL $\left( 1 1 9 5 . 4 0 \mathrm { ~ m } ^ { 2 } \mathrm { ~ g } ^ { - 1 } \right.$ and $0 . 7 0 \ \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 } \ \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 } )$ are larger than those of LDMC-MAL $\left( 7 6 3 . 7 7 \ \mathrm { ~ m } ^ { 2 } \ \mathrm { ~ g } ^ { - 1 } \right.$ and $0 . 2 7 ~ \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 } ~ \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 } )$ . Notably, the mesoporosity of LDMC-DAL $( 5 3 \% )$ was much higher than that of LDMC-MAL $( 2 2 \% )$ , further highlighting an obvious improvement of lignin reactivity to­ wards formaldehyde after DES-W-1/4 pretreatment, which verifies the pretreatment effectiveness of DES-W-1/4 on MAL.
3.4. Electrochemical performance of LDMCs

CV curves (Fig. 6a and Fig. 6d) show that two LDMC samples pre­ pared by replacing phenol absolutely with DAL-W-1/4 and MAL display a quasirectangular and mirror shape at scan rates of $5 \ \mathrm { m V } { \cdot } s ^ { - 1 }$ and $5 0 0 \ \mathrm { m V } { \cdot } s ^ { - 1 }$ , which suggests a typical electric double-layer capacitor behavior, high electrochemical reversibility and rate performance [49]. And the slight deformation of the rectangle at the high scan rate of $5 0 0 \ \mathrm { m V } { \cdot } \mathbf { s } ^ { - 1 }$ could be due to the enlargement of channel defect [50]. More importantly, compared with LDMC-MAL, LDMC-DAL has a much larger CV curve integral area, indicating a better electrochemical performance.

img_caption: Fig. 5. TEM images of (a) LDMC-DAL and (b) LDMC-MAL, (c) SAXS diagrams of LDMCs, (d) Raman spectra of LDMCs, (e) ${ \bf N } _ { 2 }$ adsorption-desorption isotherms of LDMCs and (f) pore size distribution curves of LDMCs.

table_caption: Table 1 Structural properties of LDMCs prepared from MAL and DAL-W-1/4 with the substitution degree of phenol of $1 0 0 \%$ .
table_footnote: a The specific surface area is calculated using BET model. b The total pore volume is calculated using single-point method at $\mathrm { P } / \mathrm { P } _ { 0 } = 0 . 9 9 5$ . c The mesopore volume and diameter are calculated using BJH model. d $P _ { \mathrm { { m e s o } } }$ means mesoporosity $= V _ { \mathrm { { m e s o } } } / V _ { \mathrm { { t o t a l } } } \times 1 0 0 \%$ . e The average pore size is calculated using NLDFT model.

img_caption: Fig. 6. Electrochemical tests in $6 ~ \mathrm { m o l ~ L } ^ { - 1 }$ KOH. (a) and (d) Cyclo-voltammograms at $5 \ \mathrm { m V } { \cdot } s ^ { - 1 }$ and $5 0 0 \ \mathrm { m V } { \cdot } s ^ { - 1 }$ , respectively; (b) and (e) Galvanostatic chargedischarge curves at $0 . 2 \mathrm { ~ A ~ g ^ { - 1 } }$ and $1 0 \mathrm { ~ A ~ g ^ { - 1 } }$ , respectively; (c) Specific volumetric capacitance calculated from galvanostatic charge-discharge curve; $\mathrm { ( f ) }$ Nyquist plots; of LDMCs; (g) Long-term cycling tests at $1 0 \mathrm { ~ A ~ g ^ { - 1 } }$ and (h) Ragone plots of LDMCs.

text: Interestingly, the GCD curves (Fig. 6b and e) of two LDMC samples exhibit the shape of highly linear symmetrical triangular at current densities of $0 . 2 \mathrm { A g } ^ { - 1 }$ and $1 0 \mathrm { A g ^ { - 1 } }$ , which demonstrates that LDMCs have a ideal electric double-layer capacitor behavior and excellent Coulombic efficiency [51]. And there is no obvious voltage drop even at high cur­ rent density of $1 0 \mathrm { A g } ^ { - 1 }$ , highlighting a lower equivalent series resistance and good rate performance [8]. As shown in Fig. 6c, it is worth noting that the specific capacitances of LDMCs calculated from GCD curves decrease gradually with increasing current density. Notably, at the same current density, the specific capacitance of LDMC-DAL is more than twice that of LDMC-MAL probably due to the fact that LDMC-DAL can provide higher specific surface area, orderliness [48] and more suitable ratio of micropores to mesopores [52]. The specific capacitance of LDMC-DAL at current density of $0 . 2 \mathrm { ~ A ~ g ^ { - 1 } }$ is as high as $1 9 7 . 3 2 \mathrm { ~ F ~ g } ^ { - 1 }$ . Furthermore, at high current density of $2 0 \mathrm { A g ^ { - 1 } }$ , the specific capacitance retention rate of LDMC-DAL $( 8 4 \% )$ is higher than that of LDMC-MAL $( 6 7 \% )$ , further highlighting a better rate performance of the former probably owing to its relatively low resistance and high response to large current [53].

In addition, Nyquist curves in Fig. 6f show that the slash slope in the low frequency region of LDMC-DAL is much higher than that of LDMCMAL, suggesting that LDMC-DAL has lower warburg diffusion resistance compared to LDMC-MAL [4]. As mentioned above, LDMC-DAL has higher mesoporosity and orderliness, as well as the uniform inter­ penetrating mesoporous channels, which can not only promote the surface area of accessibility, but also provide wider transmission path to help electrolyte ions reach the micropores [7,51]. Moreover, the higher degree of graphitization of LDMC-DAL can enhance its conductivity and reduce the internal resistance of electron transfer [54]. Meanwhile, compared to LDMC-MAL, the Nyquist curve of LDMC-DAL in the high frequency region has a smaller semicircular diameter and lower apex, showing its lower Warburg impedance.

As is known, cycling stability is another important indicator for evaluating the electrochemical performance of electrode material. To study the electrochemical performances of LDMC-MAL and LDMC-DAL thoroughly, the stability of galvanostatic charge-discharge cycle was tested at current density of $1 0 \mathrm { A g } ^ { - 1 }$ , and the result is shown in Fig. 6g. It is observed from Fig. 6g that both LDMC-DAL and LDMC-MAL show superior capacitance retention $( > 9 0 \% )$ after 10000 cycles. More impressively, LDMC-DAL has a higher capacitance retention $( 9 9 . 0 9 \% )$ than LDMC-MAL $( 9 5 . 1 5 \% )$ , reflecting an improved electrochemical stability of the former.

Moreover, energy density and power density calculated from GCD curves are shown in Fig. 6h. Seen from Fig. 6h, at the same power density, the energy density of LDMC-DAL is more than twice that of LDMC-MAL. For LDMC-DAL, the maximum energy density reaches $6 . 8 5 ~ \mathrm { W h } { \cdot } \mathbf { k g } ^ { - 1 }$ at power density of $1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { W ~ k g ^ { - 1 } }$ , and its energy density still retains 5.72 Wh∙ $\mathbf { k g } ^ { - 1 }$ when power density is as high as $1 0 0 0 0 \mathrm { W } \mathrm { k g } ^ { - 1 }$ , which is better than those of carbon materials reported in literature, such as OMC (5.41 Wh∙ $\mathbf { k g } ^ { - 1 }$ at $5 . 0 3 \mathrm { k W } \mathrm { k g } ^ { - 1 } )$ [55], ASCH-1:1 (4.4 ${ \mathrm { W h } } \cdot { \mathrm { k g } } ^ { - 1 }$ at $2 4 8 \ \mathrm { ~ W ~ } \ \mathrm { k g } ^ { - 1 } )$ [56], FA-Bu-MC $( 2 . 7 ~ \mathrm { \ W h } \cdot \mathrm { k g } ^ { - 1 }$ at $2 5 1 6 ~ \mathrm { ~ W ~ } ~ \mathrm { k g } ^ { - 1 } )$ [57], reed straw-derived carbon $( 6 . 1 2 ~ \mathrm { \ W h } \cdot \mathrm { k g } ^ { - 1 }$ at $4 6 6 0 ~ \mathrm { W } ~ \mathrm { k g } ^ { - 1 } ;$ ) [58], three-dimensional activated carbon $( 4 . 2 7 ~ \mathrm { W h } \cdot \mathrm { k g } ^ { - 1 }$ at 405.6 W $\mathbf { k g } ^ { - 1 } .$ ) [59], three-dimensional hierarchical porous carbon $( 3 . 7 5 ~ \mathrm { W h } \cdot \mathbf { k g } ^ { - 1 }$ at 1070 W $\mathbf { k g } ^ { - 1 } .$ ) [60].
4. Conclusions

In summary, the modification of MAL was carried out via DES pre­ treatment. Notably, it was observed that a proper amount of water added substantially enhanced the pretreatment efficiency through tun­ ing the properties of acidic DES. The optimized DES-pretreated lignin (DAL-W-1/4) with ArOH content of $3 . 3 6 ~ \mathrm { m m o l g ^ { - 1 } }$ and particle size of $4 0 0 \mathrm { n m }$ was obtained under the conditions of molar ratio of ChCl to F of 1:2, mass ratio of W to ChCl and F of 1:4, pretreatment time and tem­ perature of $^ { 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ and $1 2 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } .$ Interestingly, DAL-W-1/4 was a surprising candidate for replacing an entire portion of phenol in the efficient preparation of OMC with specific surface area of $1 1 9 5 . 4 0 \ \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } \ \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ , total pore volume of $0 . 7 0 \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ , pore diameter of $5 . 2 2 \mathrm { n m }$ and mesoporosity of $5 3 \%$ . Compared to LDMC-MAL, LDMC-DAL has larger specific surface area and pore volume, higher degree of graphitization and orderliness, which was beneficial for LDMC-DAL to being a superior electrode ma­ terial of supercapacitor with good electrochemical performance. This study provides a green and feasible approach to facilitate the high-value utilization of lignin in the efficient and sustainable preparation of OMC.
